subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] The principles of my dictionary
msgSnippet: ... Okay, I think seeing some concrete examples would help, so I ve come up with my own (now that I ve thought your proposal over & understand it better). The
messageBody:
Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
>

>
> The main features of the AtOx spelling are:
>
> The lexical sets LOT-CLOTH-THOUGHT are all written with the
> QS letter {Q} [^1] and TRAP-BATH-FATHER are all written with
> {a}. The resulting -- hopefully simple -- spelling rule for
> speakers who merge LOT-CLOTH-THOUGHT-FATHER (i.e. most North
> Americans) is as follows:
>
> The default spelling for /A/ is {Q} (Ox), but spell it
> with {a} (At) where the TO spelling is _a_ without a
> following _u_ or _w_.

Okay, I think seeing some concrete examples would help, so I've come up
with my own (now that I've thought your proposal over & understand it
better).

The word _thought_ is pronounced by most Americans with the same vowel
as the word _palm_, what QS represents as /A/. Under this spelling
reform proposal, _thought_ would be spelled as /TQT/. (I realize there
is an abbreviation for _thought_, but just pretend there isn't.)
Likewise, _bought_ is spelled /BQT/, _bottle_ is spelled /BQTl/, _ox_ is
spelled /Qks/, and so fourth.

Americans will have to be careful with words like _father_, however. If
you pronounce the word with a /A/ sound, but the word is spelled in TO
with an _a_ you will have to apply a special rule. (I don't need this
rule because I am from Boston, & can hear the difference--lucky me!) So
_father_ is spelled with an _a_, and not followed by _u_ or _w_, so you
spell it /faDar/. _Paul_ is also spelled with an _a_, but it is followed
by an _u_, so you spell it /pQl/.


> One possible reform would be to write FOOT-GOOSE alike with
> {U} and use {u} for /ju/: it would make another major
> difference between British and American English less
> disturbing: in words like _tune, duke, suit, nude_ (i.e.
> where 'long _u_' follows _t, d, s, n_ and at least
> theoretically _z_) Britons pronounce _u_ as /ju/ but
> Americans pronounce it as /u/, which would make a spelling
> without an explicit {j} desirable. Moreover some accents in
> Britain have a true diphthong /IU/ wherever other accents
> have 'long _u_', including words like _lute_ and _rude_, so
> that for them a spelling with a {j} in these words will be
> as inappropriate as a spelling which renders _u_ in _tune_
> and _lute_ differently. To abandon Read's {j_u} ligature
> would however change word outlines radically, and the
> required spelling rule is simple as is:
>
> Write TO 'long _u_' with {j_u} except after _l_ and _r_.
>
> Americans will have to remember that {j} after {t, d, n} is
> silent, and to insert it appropriately, much as non-rhotic
> speakers have to insert {r}. For speakers of /IU/ accents QS
> spelling was and will be rather illogical, but they will
> have to defer to the majority.
>

What if we just never used /j/ before /IU/? Wouldn't that be a simpler
rule for everyone to follow? I can't think of an instant where that
would cause confusion, except at the beginning of a word, in why case
use the /j/: /junYtad/ /ju tri/. Though I guess even at the beginning
you could leave out the /j/.

You spelling proposal is attractive. Americans can still use their ear
to spell words except for words in the PALM lexical set, which I am to
understand is very small. I assume that if British spell all PALM words
and all BATH words with /a/, we will have consistent spelling; likewise,
I assume consistent spelling if British speakers use /Q/ for both
THOUGHT and LOT lexical sets.

I think my dictionary could be used if this spelling reform is adapted.
It separates out words by the LOT, TRAP, and THOUGHT sets. It does not
separate out words in the BATH lexical set. Nor does it separate words
in the CLOTH lexical set. However, I think if all the PALM words are
changed to /a/, and all the LOT and THOUGHT words are changed to /Q/, we
get the desired spelling.

Paul
